name: barite production | barite | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/11878/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of barite. Barite is the mineralogical name for barium sulfate. Barite refers here to the first marketable product, which includes crude barite that usually has undergone simple beneficiation processes, such as jigging, tabling, and washing, or more complex processes, such as flotation, heavy-media separation, or magnetic separation. Most barite ores require some upgrading to minimum commercial purity or density levels.;Barite is primarily used as a weighting agent in oil and gas well drilling fluids or 'mud'.;The inventory is based on literature data and estimations.;References:;Jungbluth N. (2007) Erdöl. In: Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz (ed. Dones R.). Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.;Bonel K. A., British Geological Survey (2005) Barytes

From extraction of barite ore in the ground.

This activity ends with the production of barite that has undergone beneficiation in order to be marketable. The dataset includes infrastructure use, energy consumption, water use and particle emissions. Land use is included in infrastructure, for which the infrastructure for a bentonite quarry has been used as a proxy.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The data is based originally on a publication in the US.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Barite is mined both in open pit and underground mines. About 60 to 120 kg of Barite can be yielded from one cubic meter of ore. The ore is transported via lorry (usually less than 5km) to a washing installation. Subsequently, it is separated from the water and grinded wet or dry. Between 65% and 85% of barite contained in the ore can be extracted. This dataset includes resource extraction and processing of the material.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description: Barite is the mineralogical name for barium sulfate. Barite refers here to the first marketable product, which includes crude barite that usually has undergone simple beneficiation processes, such as jigging, tabling, and washing, or more complex processes, such as flotation, heavy-media separation, or magnetic separation. Most barite ores require some upgrading to minimum commercial purity or density levels. Barite is primarily used as a weighting agent in oil and gas well drilling fluids or 'mud'.

exchanges.description: Calculated as a fraction of the input of water. For more details, refer to the mathematical relation and the parameters.

Literature value. This exchange accounts for the transport of the ore from the mine to the washing installation (commonly less than 5 km) (Jungbluth, 2007), i.e. transport within the boundaries of the production activity.

Reference:
Jungbluth N. (2007) Erdöl. In: Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz (ed. Dones R.). Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
